# Citations and Scholarly Features

This document demonstrates Quarto's comprehensive support for academic and scholarly writing.

## Citing Sources

### Parenthetical Citations

This is a parenthetical citation [@knuth1984]. Multiple citations work too [@knuth1984; @einstein1905].

### Narrative Citations

As noted by @wickham2015, data visualization is essential.

### Citations with Locators

The concept is discussed extensively [@knuth1984, pp. 33-35]. You can also use chapters [@knuth1984, ch. 2] or sections [@einstein1905, sec. 3].

### Citations with Prefixes and Suffixes

[See @knuth1984 for more details; also @einstein1905].

Contrary to @wickham2015, some researchers argue otherwise.

### Custom Text with Citation

[As discussed in the original paper](@knuth1984).

## In-Text References

### Author-Year Format

@knuth1984 presented the seminal work on algorithms.

### Numbered Format

If your CSL uses numbered format, citations appear as [1], [2], etc.

## Author Metadata

The document uses rich author and publication metadata:

```yaml
author: "Quarto Review Team"
date: today
abstract: "Document abstract"
keywords:
  - keyword1
  - keyword2
citation: "Citation information"
license: CC BY 4.0
```

## Citation Metadata

### Citation Information

Documents can include structured citation information:

```yaml
citation:
  type: article
  container-title: "Journal Name"
  volume: 10
  issue: 5
  pages: 123-145
  DOI: "10.1234/example"
```

### DOI

This document has DOI information in its metadata, enabling citation tracking.

## Bibliography Format

The bibliography at the end of this document uses the Chicago Manual of Style (author-date) format, as specified by the `csl` metadata field.

Different citation styles available:
- Chicago Manual of Style (author-date)
- Chicago Manual of Style (notes-bibliography)
- American Psychological Association (APA)
- Modern Language Association (MLA)
- IEEE
- And many others via the Zotero Style Repository

## Uncited References

### Using `nocite`

To include references in the bibliography without citing them in the text, use the `nocite` metadata:

```yaml
nocite: |
  @item1, @item2
```

This is useful for including related work or recommended reading.

## License Information

This document is licensed under Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 (CC BY 4.0). License information appears automatically in the appendix when specified in front matter.

## Date Handling

### Special Date Keywords

The document front matter can use:
- `date: today` - Current date
- `date: now` - Current date and time
- `date: last-modified` - File modification date

All dates are automatically formatted according to locale settings.

## Title Block Features

### Banner Title Block

To use a banner-style title, add to front matter:

```yaml
title-block-style: default
title-block-banner: "#f0f0f0"
title-block-banner-color: "black"
```

Options:
- `default`: Standard title block with styled grouping
- `plain`: Simple undecorated title block
- `none`: No title block processing

## DOI and Citation

Documents with DOI information can be made citeable through services like CrossRef.

Required metadata:
```yaml
citation:
  DOI: "10.1234/example"
  container-title: "Journal Name"
  volume: 10
  issue: 5
  pages: 123-145
```

## Reference Location Options

### Margin References

With `reference-location: margin`, footnotes and citations appear in the document margins, keeping the main text clean.

### Document References

With `reference-location: document`, citations appear in the bibliography at the document end (current setting).

### Block References

With `reference-location: block`, citations appear in a section before each block.

## Scholarly Metadata Tags

Front matter supports extensive scholarly metadata:

```yaml
author:
  - name: "First Author"
    email: "first@example.com"
    orcid: "0000-0000-0000-0000"
    affiliation:
      name: "Institution"
      address: "Street, City, State"
      url: "https://institution.edu"

keywords:
  - keyword 1
  - keyword 2

abstract: |
  Long abstract text here.
```

## Creating Citeable Articles

To make an article suitable for indexing and citation:

1. Include DOI in metadata
2. Add proper author and affiliation information
3. Include abstract and keywords
4. Use appropriate title block styling
5. Generate citations for publication in services like CrossRef

## Conclusion

Quarto's scholarly features enable:

- Flexible citation formatting using CSL styles
- Multiple citation syntax options
- Automatic bibliography generation
- Structured author and publication metadata
- License tracking and attribution
- Appendix organization
- Support for various reference locations
- Integration with academic indexing services

These features make Quarto suitable for academic papers, research articles, and scholarly publications.
